VI. 110 113 25
I examined carefully the whole
alimentary canal in order to
see if there were any peculiarity
which might account for
the fact that it ^ this animal can subsist
for months together without
drink - Some animals , such
as the Düiker (Cephalopus mergens)
or Puti (of the Bechuanas) -
The steinbuk (Tragulus Rupestris)
or Puruhuru - )
The Gemsbuck (orOryx Capensis)
or Kukama -
The Porcupine are all able to
cor subsist without water, for many
Springbuck &c &c
^ months at
a time by living on bulbs and
tubers containing moisture -
They have sharp ^ pointed hoofs well
adapted for digging, and there
is little difficulty in comprehending
their mode of subsistence -
Some animals too / on the other hand are never
seen but in the vicinity of
water - The ^ presence of the Rhinoceros - of the
The Buffalo & gnu - Catoblepas gnu of the Giraffe
the Zebra and Pallah (Antilope melampus are is
always a certain indications
of water being within a circledistance
of 7 or 8 miles - But one
may see hundreds of Elands ^
(Bosephalus oreas) Gemsbuck,
The Tolo or Khoodoos (Strepsiceros
capensis) Also and springboks (gazella Euch-
-ore
argoceros Equina Taheksi
Roan
111 114
and ostriches without being warranted
thereby to in infering the existencepresence of
water within thirty or forty
miles - Indeed the sleek fat
condition of the Eland would
in such circumstance would
not remove the apprehension
41 of perishing from thirst from
the mind of even a native I believe however
that these animals
can do so only when
there is some moisture
in the vegetation on
which they feed
for in one year
of unusual drought
we saw [herds of
Elands & flocks
of ostriches crowdeding
to the Zouga from
the Desert and very
many of the latter
were killed in
pitfalls on the
banks - With
some sap in the
pasturage they
seldom need a sip -
But should heone see the "spoor"
of a Rhinoceros or buffalo
or Zebra he would at once
follow ^ it up under the impressionwell assured
that before he had gone many
miles he would ^ certainly reach water

In the evening of our
second day at Serotli a
hyaenahyena by appearing
suddenly among
the grass succeeded in raising
a panic among our cattle
This ^ false attack is the plan which this
cowardly animal always
adopts - His courage resembles
closely that of a turkey cock - He
will bite if an animal is
running away & if the animal
stands so does he - Seventeen
of our animalsdraught oxen ran away
and in their flight went right
into the hands of Sekomi whom
from ^ his being unfriendly to our
success we had no particular
wish to see - Cattle stealing
such as in the circumstances
might have occurred in Caffraria
is here unknown - So
112 115
SekhomiSekomi sent back our oxen
and a message strongly dis-
-suading me against attempting
the desert - Where are you going? "You will be killed
by the sun and thirst and then
all the white men will blame
me for not saving you - " This
was backed by a private message
from his mother - "Why do
you pass me? I always made
the people collect to hear that
word you have got - What
guilt have I that you pass
without looking at me" -
We replied by assuring the messengers
that white men would
attribute our deaths to our
own stupidity & "hard headedness"
(tlogo, e thata) as we did not
intend to allow our companions
and guides to return till they
had put us into our graves"
We sent a handsome present
to Sekomi and a promise ^ that if
he allowed the Bakalahari
to keep the wells open for
us we shwould repeat the gift ^
on our return After using upexhausting all their eloquence
in fruitless attempts to persuade
us to return - "Who is taking
them" said the underchief who
headed the party of ^ Sekomi's messengers
Looking round he saidexclaimed with
a face expressive of the most
113 116
unfeigned disgust - "It is Ra-
-Motobi"! He belonged to Sekomi
but had fled to Sechele and
as fugitives in this country are
always well recievedreceived and
may even afterwards visit
the tribe from which they have
escaped Ramotobi was in
no danger though doing that which
he knew to be directly opposed
to the interests of his own chief
and tribe -

Coultait All around Serotli the country
is perfectly flat & composed
of soft white sand - There is
a peculiar glare of whbright sun-
-light from a cloudless sky
over the whole scene - And
one clump of trees and bushes
with open spaces between,
looks so exactly like another
that if you leave the wells
and walk a quarter of a
mile in any direction it is
difficult to return - OswelOswell &
Murray went out on one
occasion to get an Eland
and were accompanied by
one of the Bakalahari - The
perfect sameness of the country
made even this ^ son sun of the desert
lose his way . , and ^ ^ A most puzzling
conversation forthwith
ensued between them
& their guide. one of the
most common words of the
people beingis "Kia itumela" - I
thank you, or I am pleased,
114 117
and the gentlemen were both quite
familiar with it and ^ with the word "metse"
= water But there is
a similar word ^ ^ very similar in
sound - "Kia timela"
I am wandering ,; and its perfect is
"Ki timetse" I have wandered -
They The party had been wandereding about perfectly
lost till the sun went down -
and ^ through their mistaking the verb "wander" for
"to be pleased" and "water" The colloquy
went on at intervals during the
whole bitterly cold night in
somewhat the following style
Where are the waggons?

SuppReal answer - I dontdon't know
I have wandered I never
wandered before - I am quite
lost -

Supposed answer I dontdon't know
I want water I am glad, I
am quite pleased, I am
thankfulys to you -

Take us to the waterggons
and you will get plenty
of water

Real answer (Looking
vacantly around) How did
I wander? perhaps the well
is there perhaps not I dontdon't
know I am wandered -

Supposed response - something
about thanks - he says he is
please and mentions water
again - The vacant stare
trying to remember is thought
115 118 30
to indicate mental imbecility
"Well Livingston has played
us a pretty trick giving us
in charge of an idiot - Catch
me trusting him again - What
can this fellow mean by his
thanks and talk about water
O you born fool take us to
the waggons and you will
get both meat and water -
Wouldn't a thrashing bring him
to his senses again - ? No No
for then he will run away
and we shall be worse off
than we are now" The hunters
regained the waggons next
day by their own sagacity which
becomes ^ wonderfully quickened by life
in the desert - and we enjoyed
a hearty laugh inon the explanation
of their midnight colloquies -
Frequent mistakes of that this
kind occur - A man may tell
his interpreter to say he is a
member of the ^ family of the chief of the white
men - "Yes, you speak like a chief"
is the reply ^ meaning, that a chief may talk
nonsense without any one
daring to contradict him -
They probably have ascertained
from that same interpreter
that this of the white chief's relative his
very poor having scarcely
anything in his waggon

116 119
I sometime felt annoyed at
the low estimation in which
some of my hunting friends
were held - for believing
that the chase is eminently con-
ducive to the formation of a
brave & noble character, and that the
contest with wild beasts is well
adapted for fostering that coolness
on emergencies and active presence
of mind which we all admire
I was naturally anxious to
havethat a high estimate of my
countrymen ^ should be formed in the
native mind - "TheHave these hunters
who come so far and work so
hard no meat at home?" Why
these men are rich and could
slaughter oxen every day of
their lives" - And yet they
come here and endure so much
thirst for the sake of this dry
meat - none of which is equal
to beef - ? Yes, it is for the sake
of play besides - (the idea of sport not
being in the language) This pro-
duces a laugh as much as
to say "Ah you know better" or
"your friends are fools" - When
they can get a man to kill
large quantities of game for
them - whatever he may think
they pride themselves in having
adroitly turned the folly of an
117 120
itinerant butcher to good account

Robinson The water ^ having at last flowed
into the wells we had dug in
sufficient quantity to allow
a good drink to all our
cattle & we departed from Serotli
in the afternoon but as the
sun even in winter as it now
was is always very powerful
by day the waggons ^ were dragged
but slowly heavily through the deep ^ heavy sand
& we made no more than six miles before
sunset - We could only travel
in the mornings and evenings
as a single day in the hot sun
and heavy sand would have
knocked up the oxen - Next
day we pastsed Pepacheu - (white
tufa) a hollow lined with tufa
in which water sometimes
stands but it was now dry
and at night our trocheamer
shewedshowed ^ that we had made but
two25 miles from Serotli Ra-
motobi was angry at the
slowness of our progress
and told us that the ^ next water being
three days in front if we
travelled so slowly we should
never get there at all - OurThe
utmost utmost endeavours
of the servants , by cracking their of
whips - screaming & beating
118 121
got only nineteen miles out of the
poor beasts - We had thus
got ^ proceeded 44 miles away from
Serotli and the oxen were beingwere were
more exhausted by the soft soft
nature of the country than
if they had travelled double the
distance ^ at atover a hard countryroad
containing water; we had still
as far as we could judge
still 30 miles more of the same
dry work before us them - The
grass wasbecomes so dry as
to crumble to powder in the
hands at this season - So the oxen they
poor beasts stood wearily chewing without
taking a single fresh mouthful
and lowing painfully at the
smell of water in our
vessels in the waggons -
We were all determined to
succeed, so endeavoured to
save the horses by sending
them forward with the guide
as a means of making
a desperate effort in case
the oxen should fail - Murray
went forward with them
horses while OswelOswell and I
remained in order to bring the
waggons ^ on on their trail As far as the cattle
could drag them intending and then to send
them oxen forward too - The horses
walked quickly away from
119 122 34
away from us and when
on the morning of the third day
we imagined the steeds must
be near the water they were
just alongside the waggons - The
guide ^ had come across the fresh
footprints of some Bushmen who had gone
in an opposite
direction to that
we wished him
to go
and turninged aside to follow
thesem found an antelope had
^ been ensnared in one of their Bushmen pitfalls
Murray ^ who had followed Ramotobi
most trustingly along the
Bushmen spoor, though
that led them both
away from
the water
we were in
search of away back to Serotli,
viewed the operation of
obscure QuQuery slaughtering ^ skinning & cutting up the düiker and
˄ antelope then after a hard day's toil found
himself close upon the waggons
The knowledge of this trackless
waste of scrub through which
we were now passing, still
retained by Ramotobi seemed
to me admirable - I could only
see To me one clump of bushes &
trees ^ seemed exactly like another but
as we walked together this
morning he remarked "when
we come to that hollow we
shall light upon the highway
of SekhomiSekomi" - and there beyond
that again lies the river
Mokoko which though we
passed along ^ it I could not
percieveperceive to be, a river bed at all
120 123 35
After breakfast some ^ of the men who had
gone forward on a little path
with some footprints of water
loving animals upon it returned
with the joyful tidings of water
"metse" water, exhibiting the
mud on their knees in con-
firmation of the news being
true - It does ones heart good
to see the thirsty oxen rush into
a pool of delicious rain water
as this ^ was was named Mathuluani
was - They rush inIn they dash untilluntil the
water is deep enough to rise nearly
level with theeir throat and then
they stand drawing slowly in the
long refreshing mouthfuls
untilluntil their formerly collapsed sides
distend as if they would burst -
So much do they imbibe ˄ that a
sudden jerk when ^ they come out on the
bank ^ bank ^ again makes some ^ of the water run out
again ^ from their mouths - but as they have been
days without food too
they very soon commence
to graze and of grass there
is always abundance every-
where - This pool was called
Mathuluani; and thankful we
were to have obtained so welcome
a supply of water.

After giving the cattle a rest at this spot
by this Providential supply of
water we proceeded down
the dry ^ bed of the river bed Mokoko - The
name refers to the water bearing
stratum before alluded to and
in this ancient bed it bears
enough of water to admit of
of ^ permanent wells in several parts of
it - We had now the assurance
from Ramotobi that we should
suffer no more from thirst
Twice we found rain water
in the Mokoko before we
reached Mokokonyani where
the water, generally below ground ˄ elsewhere
comes to the surface in a bed
of tufa - The adjacent country
is all covered with low thorny
scrub with grass and here and
there clumps of the "wait a bit thorn"
or acacia tortuosa - At Lotlakani
(a little reed) another spring 3 miles farther down,
We met with the first Palmyra trees
They were twenty six in number which
we had seen in Africa - The
ancient Mokoko must have
been joined by other rivers below
this for it becomes very
broad and then spread [out
into a large lake of which
the lake that we were now in search
of formed but a very small
part - We observed that whe˄rever
122 125
an anteater had made his hole
shells were thrown out with
the earth which are identical
with those now alive in the
Lake -

When we left the Mokoko
Ramotobi seemed for the first
time to be at a loss as to which
direction to traveltake - He had passed
only once away to the West of
the Mokoko the scenes of his
boyhood - But Mr OswelOswell while
riding in front of the waggons
happened to spy a Bushwoman
running away in a bent
position in order to escape
observation - Thinking it to be
a lion he galloped ^ up to her - She
thought herself captured and
began to deliver up her poor
little property consisting of a few
traps made of cords - But when
I explained that we only
wanted water and would
pay her if she led us to it she
consented to conduct us to a
spring - It was then late in the
afternoon but she walked
briskly before our horses
for eight miles and shewedshowed
us the water of Nchokotsa -
After leading us to the water she
wished to go away home if
indeed such she had ^ any, (she had
fled from a party of her
123 126
countrymen and was now living
far from all other & water
with her husband) but as it was
now dark we wished her to
remain - ^ as she Believinged herself still
a captive, we thought she might
slip away by night, so in
order that she mightshould not go away
with the impression that we
were dishonest - we gave her
a piece of meat and a good
large bunch of beads, at the
sight of the latter she burst
into a merry laugh and
remained without suspicion

Carp At Nchokotsa we came
upon the first of a great
number of salt pans
covered with an efflorescence
of lime & nitrate of soda ? A thick belt of
Mopane trees hides this ^ salt pan - which
is of 20 miles in circumference -
entirely from the view of a
person coming from the
Eastern side south East and
at the time the pan burst upon
our view the setting sun was
casting a bleautiful blue haze
over the white incrustations
making the whole look exactly
like a Lake - OswelOswell threw his
hat up in the air at the sight
and shouted out a huzza which
made the poor Bushwoman
and Bakwains think him mad -
124 127
I was a little behind him and was
as completely decieveddeceived by it as he
but as we had agreed to allow
each other to seebehold the Lake it at the same
instant I felt a little chagrin
that he had unintentionally
got the first glance - We had
no idea that the long looked
for Lake was still more then
300 miles distant - The ^ One reason
of our mistake was ^ that the river Zouuga was often
spoken of by the same name
as the Lake viz - videlicet Noka ea Botletli

Looking to the West ^ & NorNorth West from
Nchokotsa we could see columns
of black smoke exactly like
those from a steam engine
rising to the clouds and were
assured that these ^ arose camefrom the
reeds of the Noka ea Botletli on
fire - The mirage on these
salinas was marvellous - It
is never I believe seen in
perfection except over these saline
incrustations - Here not a
particle of imagination was
necessary for realising the
exact picture of large
collections of water - The waves
danced along above and the
shadows of the trees were
vividly reflected beneath the
surface in such an admirable
manner that the loose cattle
125 128 40
whose thirst has not been slaked
sufficiently by the very brackish
water of Nchokotsa - with the
horses, dogs and even the
Hotentots ran off towards the
deceitful pools - A herd of Zebras
in the mirage ^ looked so exactly like Elephants
that OswelOswell began to saddle a horse
in order to hunt them - but a
sort of ^ break in the haze dispelled the
illusion - ^ on the 4th July We went forward
on horseback towards what
we supposed to be the Lake
and again and again did
we seem to see it but at
last we came to the veritable
water of the Zouga and found it to be
a river running to the N. NE.North East
A village of Bakurutse ^ lay
on the opposite bank These live
among Batletli
a tribe having
a click in their
language and
who were found
by Sebituane to
possess large
herds of the
great horned
cattle - They seem
allied to the
Hottentot family - Mr OOswell
in trying to cross the river got
his horse nearly bogged in
the swampy bank - Two Bakwains
and I managed to get over
by wading beside a fishing weir
The people were friendly and
informed us that this water
came out of the Ngami - This
news thgladdened all our hearts
for we now felt certain of
reaching our goal - We might
they said be a moon in the
way but we had the river
Zouga at our feet and by
126 129
and by following it we should
at last reach the broad water -

Wilkes Next day when we were
quite disposed to be friendly
with every one, two of the
Bamangwato, who had
been sent on before us
by Sekomi to drive away
all the Bushmen and
Bakalahari from our path,
came and sat down by our
fire - We had seen their footsteps
fresh in the way, and they had
watched our slow movements
forward, and wondered to
see how we, without any
bushmen, found our way
to the waters - This was the
first time they had seen
Ramotobi - "You have reached
the river now", said they;
and we, quite disposed to laugh
as having won the game, felt
no ill will to any one - They
felt no enmity to us, but
after friendly conversation with
us proceeded to fulfill to the
last the instructions of their
chief = (.) Ascending the Zouga
in our front, they circulated
the report that our objects
were to plunder all the tribes
living on the river and Lake;
But when ^ they had got half way up the
127 130
river, the principal man
sickened of fever, turned
back some distance, and died
His death had some effect
for the villagers connected
it with the injury he was
attempting to do to us - They
all saw through Sekomi's
reasons for wishing us to
fail in our attempt; and
though they cam armed to
us at first, kind & fair
treatment soon produced
perfect confidence

When we had gone up the
bank of this beautiful river
about 96 miles from the point
where we first struck it, and
understood that we were still
a considerable distance from
the Ngami, all the waggons
and oxen were lefthere except Mr
OswelOswell's, which was the smallest
and one team, - in the hope that
they rest would be recruited for
the home journey, while we
made a push for the Lake -
The Bechuana chief of the lake
region, who had sent men to
Sechele, now sent order to
all the people on the river to
assist us, and we were
recievedreceived by the Bakoba, whose
language ^ clearly shewsshows they bear
128 131
an affinity to the tribes in the
North - (.) They call themselves
Bayeiye, i-e-id est men; but the
Bechuanas use the term Bakoba,
which contains somewhat of
the idea of slaves. - They have
never been known to fight,
and indeed have a tradition
that their forefathers in their
first essays at war made
their bows of the Palma Christi;
and when these broke, they
gave up fighting altogether. - They
have invariably submitted
to the rule of every horde which
has overrun the countries
adjacent to the rivers on
which they specially love to
dwell. - They are thus the Quakers
of the body politic in Africa -

Robinson A ( Long ^ time after ^ the period of our visit this the
chief of the Lake, thinking to
make soldiers of them, took
the trouble to furnish them
with shields. - "Ah! we never
had these before; that is the
reason we have always
succumbed. - Now we will
fight - " But a marauding
party came from the Makololo,
trtranspose and our ^ "Friends" scouriedscurried at once
away down the Zouga, - never
daring to once looking behind them
till they reached the end of it
where we first saw it - )

129 132
The canoes of these inland
sailors are truly primitive craft:
They are hollowed out of the
trunks of single trees by means
of iron adzes; and if the tree
has a bend, so has the canoe(.)
I liked the frank and manly
bearing of these inland sailors,
and instead of sitting in the
waggon preferred a seat
in ^ one of the canoes. - I found
they regarded their rude vessels
as the Arab does his camel(.)
They have always a fires in
them each, and prefer sleeping in
them while on a journey to
spending the night on shore(.)
"On land you have lions," - say
they; - "serpents, hyaenashyenas, and
your enemies; but in your
canoe behind a bank of
reed nothing can harm you - "
Their submissive disposition
leads to their villages being frequently
visited by hungry strangers (-) We
had a pot on the fire oin the
canoe by the way, and when
we drew near the villages
devoured the contents (-) When
fully satisfied ourselves, I found
we could all look upon
any intruders with perfect
complacency, and shewshow the
pot in proof of having devoured
the last morsel -

130 45 133
While ascending in this way
this beautifully wood ^ ed river,
we came to a large riverstream
flowing into it - : This was / the
River ^ Tamunak'le(.) I enquired
whence it came(.) "O, from a
country full of river - so
many no one can tell their
number, and full of large
trees -" This was the first con-
firmation of statements I had
heard from the Bakwains, ofwho
had been with Sebituane, that
the country beyond was not
"athe large sandy plateau" of
the philosophers - The prospect
of a highway into the capable of
being traversed by boats
to an entirely unexplored
and very populous region
grew from that time forward
greater and greater in my
bosommind - So when we actually
came to the Lake, ^ itthe idea occupied
such a large portion of my
mental vision that discovery
seemed of but little importance(:)
I find I wrote when the emotions
caused by the magnificent
prospects of the new country
were first awaked in my
breast bosom, that they "might subject
me to the charge of enthusiasm,
a charge bywhich I wished
I deserved, as nothing ^ good or great"
131 134
"had ever been accomplished
in the world without it." *

Daintree & Co.Company Twelve days after our
departure from the waggons
at Ngabisane we came to
the North East end of Lake
Ngami and on the 1st August
1849 we went down together
to the broad part and for
the first time this fine looking
sheet of water was beheld
by Europeans Eyes - The direction
of the Lake seemed to be N. N - E -North North East
and S - S - W - South South West ^ by compass The Southern portion
is said to bend a little round
to the West, & to recievereceive the Teoughe
from the North at its N - WNorth West
extremity - We could detect no
horizon where we stood looking
S - S - W -South South West We could form no
idea of its extent except from
nativethe reports ^ of the natives and as they
professed to go round it in
three days, allowing 25 miles
a day that would bemake it 75 or
less than 70 geographical
miles in circumference - Other
guesses have been made since
as to its circumference, and they rangeing between 70
and 100 miles in circumference
* Letters published by the Royal Geographical
society - Read - 11th Feb.February & 8 April 1850
132 135
It is shallow for I subsequently
saw a native punting his
canoe over 7 or 8 miles of
the N - E -North East end , and ^ it can never
be of much value as a
commercial highway - In
the months preceding the
annual supply of water
from the North it ^ the Lake is so lowshallow
that it is with difficulty ^ that cattle
can approach the water
through the boggy reedy banks
These are low on all sides
but on the West there is a
space devoid of trees shewingshowing
that the waters have retired
from thence at no very
ancient date - This is just
another of the proofs of
desiccation somet ^ with so abundantly
throughout in the whole country - A
number of dead trees lie on
this space - Some of them
embedded in the mud right
in the water - We were informed
by the Bayeiye who live on
the lake that when the annual
inundation begins, not
only trees of great size but
Antelopes as the Springbuck
and Tsessebe (acronotus Lunata)
are swept down by its rushing
waters - and the trees are
gradually driven ^ wafted by the winds gradually
to the opposite [side & become
49)embedded in mud
133 136 48
The water of the Lake is perfectly
fresh when full - but
brackish when low and that coming down
the Tamunakle we found
to be so clear cold and soft
the higher we ascended ^ that the
idea of ^ melting snow was suggested
to our minds - We found
the region to be clearly a
hollow - The point of the
ebullition of water ^ as shown by one of
Newman's barometric thermometer
beingwas only between 207½1/2 & 206°, giving
an elevation of not much
more than 2000 feet above
the level of the sea - We had
descended other above 2000 feet
in coming to it from Kolobong -
It is the Southern & lowest
part of the great river system
beyond - In itwhich large tracts
of country are inundated
annually by Tropical rains
hereafter to be described -
A little of that water which in
